metadata.title: Title: Chloroquine Kills Hair Cells in Zebrafish Lateral Line and Murine Cochlear Cultures: 1 Implications for Ototoxicity 2

abstract.text: Abstract: Hearing and balance deficits have been reported during and following treatment 28 with the antimalarial drug chloroquine. However, experimental work examining the direct 29 actions of chloroquine on mechanoreceptive hair cells in common experimental models is 30 lacking. This study examines the effects of chloroquine on hair cells using two common 31 experimental models: the zebrafish lateral line and neonatal mouse cochlear cultures. 32

Zebrafish larvae were exposed to varying concentrations of chloroquine phosphate or 33 hydroxychloroquine for 1 hr or 24 hr, and hair cells assessed by antibody staining. A 34 significant, dose-dependent reduction in the number of surviving hair cells was seen 35 across conditions for both exposure periods. Hydroxycholroquine showed similar toxicity. 36

In mouse cochlear cultures, chloroquine damage was specific to outer hair cells in tissue 37 from the cochlear basal turn, consistent with susceptibility to other ototoxic agents. These 38 findings suggest a need for future studies employing hearing and balance monitoring 39 during exposure to chloroquine and related compounds, particularly with interest in these 40 compounds as therapeutics against viral infections including coronavirus. 41 42 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.14.041731 doi: bioRxiv preprint Total hair cells remaining were compared to counts of the same neuromasts of untreated 162 fish or untreated cochlear cultures to calculate the percentage of hair cells remaining. Hair 163 cell survival was then related to concentration of chloroquine used in incubation. As hydroxychloroquine is often used to replace chloroquine in clinical settings, 183 these two drugs were compared for relative hair cell toxicity. Both drugs showed dose-184 dependent hair cell loss ( Figure 2 ). Hydroxychloroquine showed slightly more toxicity than 185 chloroquine (F=4.774, p=0.03; two-way ANOVA). These results demonstrate that both 186 clinically-relevant chloroquine drugs show hair cell toxicity in the zebrafish model. 187

Previous work has demonstrated that quinoline drugs, including chloroquine, can 188 inhibit aminoglycoside ototoxicity by partially blocking mechanotransduction-dependent 189 toxin uptake (Ou et al., 2012) . We reasoned that the asymptotic nature of the chloroquine 190 dose-response function might be due to its ability to block its own uptake. We performed 191 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Function of the mechanotransduction channel 192 was assessed through quantification of FM1-43X uptake after pre-treatment with 193 chloroquine at doses that cause maximal hair cell death. Fish were also treated with 194 benzamil, a MET channel blocker known to block drug uptake ( implying that chloroquine uptake is rapid and affects hair cells soon after they are exposed. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.14.041731 doi: bioRxiv preprint and organ of Corti, especially to outer hair cells (Hennebert and Fernández, 1959). 251

Exposed animals displayed minimal damage in the vestibular system, and impacted 252 vestibular function recovered with time. Peripheral auditory function was reduced with 253 quinine injections-acutely exposed animals improved fully or partially, and those receiving 254 chronic dosing remained affected. 255

The mechanism by which chloroquine acts to kill hair cells is not yet known. The 256 pharmacological mechanisms of action of chloroquine are subject of some controversy but 257 is widely considered to be due to its accumulation in lysosomes and subsequent 258 Moreover we found that interfering with mechanotransduction had little effect on 279 chloroquine toxicity. We suggest that there may be other reasons for incomplete toxicity in 280 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF0.text: and OC1) per fish using a Zeiss Axioplan II microscope at a total magnification of 200X 135 (40X objective; N.A.=0.75) with FITC filtered fluorescent illumination. 136 137 2.2 Cochlear cultures 138 Cochlear cultures were prepared from C57BL/6J mice according to previously 139 described protocols (Kitcher et al., 2019; Russell and Richardson, 1987). Explants were 140 prepared from pups sacrificed at postnatal day 2 and plated on collagen covered 141 coverslips with 50 µL of cochlear culture medium (93% DMEM-F12, 7% FBS and 10 μg/ml 142 ampicillin). The culture and coverslip were incubated overnight in a Maximow slide 143 assembly at 37˚C. 144 Experiments were carried out in 2 mL total volume of modified culture media 145 (98.6% DMEM-F12, 1.4% FBS and 10 μg/ml ampicillin) with varying concentration of 146 chloroquine. After 24 hours of incubation, cultures were washed once with PBS, fixed in 147 4% paraformaldehyde for 1 hour at room temperature. Hair cells were labeled with 1:1000 148 Phalloidin conjugated to Alexa Fluor 568 (Invitrogen, A12380) and 1:1000 anti-Myosin-VIIa 149 rabbit polyclonal antibody (Santa Cruz, sc-74516), 1:1000 anti-Sox2 polyclonal antibody 150 overnight followed by 1:500 Alexa Fluor 488 and 1:500 Alexa Fluor 694 goat anti-rabbit 151 IgG (Invitrogen, A-11034). 152 Tissue was imaged at the midpoint of the apical region and at the midpoint of the 153 basal region of the cochlear coil using an Axioplan ll (Zeiss) upright microscope at a final 154 magnification of 200x. MyosinVIIa labeled hair cell bodies and Sox2 labeled support cell 155 nuclei were counted in a 100 µm length along the sensory epithelium of each microscope 156 field. A statistical power analysis based on previous experiments in this system, with an 157 alpha of 0.05 and power = 0.80 indicated that a minimum of n= 4 samples per group 158 would be required (Rosner, 2011). 159 160 2.3 Data Analysis 161 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF1.text: the potential toxic effects of chloroquine, zebrafish were treated with 169 differing concentrations of drug. Neuromasts displayed clearly visible hair cell death after 170 treatment for 24h (Figure 1A,B), with increasing hair cell loss after exposure to increasing 171 chloroquine concentrations during 24h exposure (Figure 1C). Significant differences in hair 172 cell numbers were found between control conditions and concentrations of 100 µM and 173 higher (100, 200, 400, 800, 1600) (p<0.05). Hair cell survival reached an apparent 174 asymptote around 65% with concentrations of 400 µM and higher (400, 800, 1600). In 175 subsequent experiments, concentrations were limited to 0-400 µM dosages. Figure 1D 176 compares the effects of treating zebrafish with chloroquine for 1h and 24h. Two-way 177 ANOVA with dose and exposure time as main factors yielded a highly significant main 178 effect of concentration (F=12, p<0.0001), but insignificant effects of exposure time 179 (F=3.06, p=0.0828) and a significant interaction term (F=4.5, p=0.0009). These results 180 demonstrate that chloroquine exposure results in a rapid dose-dependent loss of zebrafish 181 lateral line hair cells. 182

FIGREF2.text: Hailey et al., 2017; Rüsch 195 et al., 1994) as a positive control (Figure 3). Chloroquine pre-treatment did not significantly 196 alter FM1-43X uptake (p=0.2334; Dunn's multiple comparison test), while benzamil-treated 197 fish showed a highly significant decrease in FM1-43X uptake compared to controls 198 (p<0.0001; Figure 3 A-D). We then examined whether chloroquine toxicity itself was 199 altered by MET blockers (Figure 4). Neither 50 µM nor 200 µM benzamil co-treatment had 200 a significant effect on chloroquine toxicity (p=0.9698 and 0.4943, respectively; Sidak's 201 multiple comparison test). Together these experiments suggest that the plateau of the 202 dose-response function is not due to chloroquine effects on mechanotransduction. 203 To test whether mammalian hair cells degenerate in response to chloroquine, 204 cells and, like most other ototoxic drugs, most severely compromises basal turn describes dose-response analyses for the effects of chloroquine in the 225 zebrafish anterior lateral line and in neonatal murine cochlear cultures. Chloroquine 226 exposure was found to cause hair cell loss in both models. In zebrafish, variation in 227 exposure time (1 hr vs 24 hr) did not result in significant differences in hair cell loss, 228

FIGREF3.text: 229 Exposure to hydroxychloroquine yielded comparable results to those from chloroquine 230 exposure. For mouse cochlear cultures, reduction in hair cell counts were most dramatic in 231 basal regions and in outer hair cells, consistent with differences in the sensitivity of hair 232 cells to other ototoxins and reported hearing loss being limited to or most profound at high 233 frequencies with most other ototoxins (Bielefeld et al., 2018; Chowdhury et al., 2018; 234 Kotecha and Richardson, 1994). While there are no in vivo mammalian studies to compare 235 with the results presented here, these results are consistent with the absence of hair cells 236 with fetal exposure to chloroquine (Matz & Naunton, 1968). 237 Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine have good oral bioavailability and reach high 238 plasma levels in patients. Their pharmacokinetic profiles indicate extremely long elimination 239 half-lives on (weeks to months) and large volumes of distribution indicating significant 240 partitioning into tissues including cerebrospinal fluid (White 1985). Given these 241 pharmacokinetic characteristics, it is entirely possible that drug concentration in the inner 242 ear reach micromolar concentrations used in the experiments described here. 243 Because quinine users commonly reported similar side effects to that of patients 244 taking chloroquine, it can be posited that the effects of these structurally-related quinoline 245 drugs with the tissues of the inner ear are comparable. These results are consistent with 246 reports of audiological and vestibular dysfunction after quinine treatment for malaria 247 prophylaxis or treatment (Hennebert and Fernández, 1959; Karlsson et al., 1990; Nielsen-248 Abbring et al., 1990; Phillips-Howard and ter Kuile, 1995; Roche et al., 1990). Studies of 249 quinine ototoxicity have shown extensive damage and deterioration of the stria vascularis 250 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF4.text: disruption of their function (Kaufmann et al., 2009). Lysosomes have emerged as 259 organelles with critical signaling roles regulating many aspects of cellular function (reviewed 260 by Xu and Ren, 2015). They also play central roles in autophagy, the process by which 261 cellular components are recycled (reviewed in Parzych and Klionsky, 2014). Chloroquine's 262 effects on lysosomes are likely to have effects on diverse downstream cellular processes 263 including receptor signaling, with anti-inflammatory consequences (Wallace et al., 2012), 264 and autophagy, with anti-tumor effects (Levy et al., 2017). There may therefore be multiple 265 effects of chloroquine on hair cell function with consequences to their survival. 266 While both zebrafish and mouse cochlear hair cells are sensitive to chloroquine, 267 there are differences in the nature of the dose-response functions. Loss of zebrafish hair 268 cells approached an asymptote of about 40% reduction without further loss at higher 269 concentrations of chloroquine, while basal outer hair cells in mouse cochlear cultures 270 approach 100% loss with increasing dose. The underlying causes of asymptotic nature of 271 the zebrafish dose-response function is unknown. We hypothesized that chloroquine may 272 reduce its uptake and toxicity at higher concentrations by blocking hair cell 273 mechanotransduction, a property required for the hair cell entry of some other compounds 274 in zebrafish, including aminoglycosides and cisplatin (Thomas et al., 2012; Hailey et al. 275 2017). Although other quinoline loop derivatives have been shown to interfere with 276 mechanotransduction (Farris et al., 2004; Ou et al., 2012), we found little effect of 277 chloroquine on mechanotransduction-dependent FM1-43 dye uptake in zebrafish. 278

FIGREF5.text: research is needed to fully investigate mechanisms of hair cell death in the 283 presence of chloroquine and more broadly how this class of drugs affect patients in their 284 everyday lives. In addition to potential side effects directly detrimental to auditory 285 perception and vestibular function, changes in these perceptual outcomes can create an 286 increase in anxiety, depression, and fatigue resulting in a decrease in quality of life (Coelho 287 and Balaban, 2015; Gomaa et al., 2014; Hornsby et al., 2016; Mira, 2008; Ohlenforst et 288 al., 2017). Given the interest of chloroquine as a therapy for viral infections including Zika 289 and SARS coronaviruses (Al-Bari, 2017), it will be important to consider monitoring 290 auditory and vestibular function as these drugs are adopted to new therapies. conceptualized by SND, JAS, EWR and DWR; Investigation carried out by SND, 298 PW and EDC; Manuscript written and edited by SND, EWR and DWR. 299 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF6.text: Chloroquine causes dose-dependent hair cell loss in the zebrafish lateral line 459 system. Fluorescent imaging showed robust hair cell numbers in control neuromasts (A) 460 and reduced numbers in fish exposed to 400 µM chloroquine for 24h (B). Hair cell counts 461 show a decrease in hair cell viability as chloroquine concentration increased (F=12.28, 462 p<0.0001;C). However, there was no significant change with concentrations from 400 µM 463 to 1600 µM (p>0.05). (D) This pattern was consistent between 24-and 1-hour exposure 464 times with no statistical significance (F=3.06, p = 0.0828). Error bars represent Hydroxychloroquine causes dose-dependent effects on hair cells in the zebrafish 468 lateral line, similar to chloroquine. Dose-response functions show that hair cells exposed to 469 hydroxychloroquine (solid line) survive at a similar rate as those exposed to chloroquine 470 (dashed line) after a 24-hour treatment period. Two-way ANOVA demonstrate a small, but 471 significant effect, with hydroxychloroquine being slightly more toxic (F=4.774, p=0.03Chloroquine does not reduce MET channel activity. Fluorescent imaging showed 475 no reduction of FM1-43-X uptake with pre-exposure to chloroquine (A-C). Brn3c fish, that 476 have green fluorescent membrane markers, had no pre-treatment (A-A"), 1000 µM 477 chloroquine for 15 minutes (B-B"), or 200 µM benzamil for 15 minutes (C-C"). Dunn's 478 multiple comparisons confirmed that red fluorescence is not significantly attenuated in fish 479 pre-treated with a high dose of chloroquine (p=0.2334), while uptake is significantly lower 480 in those fish treated with benzamil (p<0.0001), a known MET channel blocker (D; n=6-8 481 fish per condition). Error bars represent ±1 standard deviation. Scale bar = 10 µm 482 Chloroquine-induced cell death is not affected by the presence of a MET channel 484 blocker. Co-treatment of chloroquine and benzamil showed no significant change in hair 485 cell viability, though chloroquine exposure did have a small but significant effect on hair cell 486 survival (p<0.0001). Error bars represent ±1 standard deviation. 487 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF7.text: Chloroquine exposure causes dose-dependent hair cell loss in neonatal mouse 488 organ of Corti cultures. (A) Fluorescent imaging of basal turn cultures treated with 0, 50, 489 100, and 200 µM chloroquine and labelled with antibodies specific to hair cells (Myosin 490 Vlla), or organ of Corti supporting cells (Sox2), or all nuclei (DAPI). Note that 50 µM 491 chloroquine exposure (row labeled 50 µM CQ) did not reveal clear loss or disruption of any 492 cell type (compare with top row (0 µM CQ). However, 100 µM and 200 µM chloroquine 493 exposure resulted in moderate and extreme loss of outer hair cells, respectively. 494 Conversely, there was no obvious loss of other cell types at any treatment condition. (B) 495 Apical coil cultures demonstrate little or no loss of inner or outer hair cells following 496 treatment with chloroquine at any of the concentrations used (p=0.6087). (C) Basal coil 497 hair cells, however, showed significantly decreased viability when treated with chloroquine 498 (p<0.0001), and outer hair cells in the base were more dramatically affected by drug 499 exposure than inner hair cells (F=26.11, p<0.0001).
